title: Ticket #4710: Valgrind error in user log writing code
description:
Note: I suspect that this bug exists in 8.2 -- if it does, it should obviously be fixed in that branch.

Anyhow, I was running valgrind on DAGMan to check some changes, and it came up with this error: 

  ==11550== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
  ==11550==    at 0x4E0D8FC: WriteUserLog::freeLogs() (write_user_log.cpp:569)
  ==11550==    by 0x4E0D334: WriteUserLog::Reset() (write_user_log.cpp:428)
  ==11550==    by 0x4E0BD43: WriteUserLog::WriteUserLog(bool) (write_user_log.cpp:93)
  ==11550==    by 0x447F1B: Dag::PostScriptReaper(Job*, int) (dag.cpp:1893)
  ==11550==    by 0x454FBC: ScriptQ::ScriptReaper(int, int) (scriptQ.cpp:180)

Here's the code: 

  void WriteUserLog::freeLogs() {
      // we do this only if local log files aren't being cached
      if (log_file_cache != NULL) return;
      for (std::vector<log_file*>::iterator j(logs.begin());  j != logs.end();  ++j) {
          delete *j;
      }
  }

This gets called in the WriteUserLog constructors without log_file_cache having been set.
remarks:
2014-Nov-08 20:31:27 by wenger:
job_dagman_basic.dag was the DAG I ran...

2014-Nov-10 18:49:44 by wenger:
Okay, this is also in 8.2. Introduced in this commit: 

  commit b4a7657edfe662a47af0ef9462140ad055d6d9e2
  Author: Erik Erlandson <eerlands@redhat.com>
  Date:   Fri Mar 21 12:26:59 2014 -0700


      Use a cache of open userlog files (and locks) to improve efficiency of
      userlog output #4040

2014-Nov-17 17:25:53 by eje:
log_file_cache is set to NULL in the Reset() method, so this patch seems to introduce a redundant initialization. Also, freeLogs() wants to know its value before it is cleared. Is this some kind of pro forma valgrind complaint?

2014-Nov-17 17:33:45 by wenger:
No, it's not a pro forma complaint. In the constructors (without my change), Reset() gets called before anything else. Then Reset() calls freeLogs() before setting log_file_cache to NULL, and the first line of freeLogs() is 

  if (log_file_cache != NULL) return;

2014-Nov-18 15:39:17 by eje:
OK I see my error, good catch. Fix looks good to me, thanks!

2014-Nov-19 12:19:09 by wenger:
Oh, yeah -- no documentation for this because, as far as we know, it didn't produce a user-visible bug.
